Gerry Smith wrote:
> Does anyone know how to get the Message variable in the Assert to print
> even if an error does not occur? I would like to put a descriptive
> message in each assert condition that I can print out for each test to
> display in the "type" field of the generated junitreport.
> 
> For instance:
> 
> Assert.assertEqual("I want to print this message pass or fail", String,
> String);
> 
> When I do this I would like to get the message in the generated
> junitreport regardless of success or failure. Any suggestions?

JUnit was designed to report nothing more than "OK" if tests pass, so 
your request goes counter to JUnit's design.

That said, here are some options:

1. Write your own assertEquals() that prints the message either way.
2. Use a logging mechanism outside JUnit to print the message right 
before the assertion.
3. Write a custom test runner with your own ResultPrinter that does what 
you want.
4. Use the JUnit-addons test runner, which allows pluggable test 
listeners, which allows you to do what you want.

I'm sure others can think of better ideas.
